expanded_description: When the economy falters, the human cost is measured in unemployment. People lose jobs, incomes fall, families struggle, and dreams are deferred. But not all unemployment is the same. Some is temporary—workers moving between jobs. Some is structural—skills mismatched with available jobs. Some is cyclical—caused by economic downturns. Understanding unemployment—how we measure it, what causes it, and why some unemployment persists—is essential for understanding the health of the economy and the effectiveness of policy. The unemployment rate is one of the most watched economic indicators, moving financial markets and influencing elections. But the unemployment rate doesn't tell the whole story. It excludes discouraged workers who've given up looking, and it counts part-time workers who want full-time work as employed. In this section, we'll explore how unemployment is defined and measured, the different types of unemployment, the costs of unemployment, and the concept of the natural rate of unemployment. You'll learn to calculate unemployment rates, interpret labor market data, and understand why some unemployment is inevitable—and even desirable—in a dynamic economy.

core_concept.principle: Unemployment refers to the number of people who are actively looking for work but are not currently employed. The unemployment rate is the percentage of the labor force that is unemployed. The labor force includes all employed and unemployed people who are either working or actively seeking work. People who are not working and not looking for work—students, retirees, stay-at-home parents, discouraged workers—are not in the labor force. The unemployment rate is calculated as: $\text{Unemployment Rate} = \frac{\text{Number Unemployed}}{\text{Labor Force}} \times 100$. The labor force participation rate is: $\frac{\text{Labor Force}}{\text{Working-Age Population}} \times 100$. Unemployment is not a single phenomenon—economists distinguish three main types: (1) Frictional unemployment—short-term unemployment from workers moving between jobs or entering the workforce; (2) Structural unemployment—long-term unemployment from mismatches between workers' skills and job requirements, often due to technological change or globalization; (3) Cyclical unemployment—unemployment caused by economic downturns, rising when aggregate demand falls. The natural rate of unemployment is the sum of frictional and structural unemployment—the rate that exists when the economy is at full employment, with no cyclical unemployment. Actual unemployment fluctuates around the natural rate over the business cycle.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine you graduate from college and start looking for a job. You're not working, but you're actively applying. You're unemployed—specifically, frictionally unemployed. After a few months, you find a job as a marketing assistant. Now you're employed. A few years later, your company is acquired and your position is eliminated. You're unemployed again—now frictionally unemployed as you search for a new job. Meanwhile, across town, a factory closes because its products can't compete with imports. The workers have skills specific to that industry and can't easily find new jobs. They're structurally unemployed—their skills don't match available jobs. Then a recession hits. The whole economy slows. Your marketing firm lays you off again. Now you're cyclically unemployed—jobless because of weak aggregate demand. Eventually the economy recovers, you find another job, and the cyclical unemployment disappears. But some structural unemployment remains—the factory workers may need retraining. And some frictional unemployment always exists as people move between jobs. The unemployment rate combines all these types. When it's high, it signals a struggling economy and human suffering. When it's very low, it can signal an overheating economy and labor shortages. Understanding unemployment helps us diagnose the economy's health and prescribe appropriate policies.

sections.introduction: Unemployment is more than a statistic—it's a measure of economic distress. When people can't find work, they lose income, skills atrophy, and families suffer. But unemployment also serves a function in a dynamic economy: workers move between jobs, industries rise and fall, and some unemployment is inevitable as the economy adjusts. Understanding unemployment means understanding these different types, how they're measured, and what they tell us about the economy. In this section, we'll learn how the government measures unemployment, the distinctions between frictional, structural, and cyclical unemployment, the concept of the natural rate, and the costs of unemployment—both economic and social. You'll learn to interpret unemployment data, understand policy debates, and recognize why full employment doesn't mean zero unemployment.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 2.3.2: The working-age population is divided into employed, unemployed (together the labor force), and not in labor force.

key_concept.definition: Unemployment is measured by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) through the Current Population Survey (CPS), a monthly survey of about 60,000 households. Individuals are classified based on their activities during the survey reference week. Employed: worked for pay at least one hour, or were temporarily absent from a job (vacation, illness). Unemployed: did not work, were available for work, and actively looked for work in the past four weeks. Not in labor force: did not work and did not look for work—students, retirees, stay-at-home parents, discouraged workers. The unemployment rate is $\frac{U}{LF} \times 100$. The labor force participation rate is $\frac{LF}{WAP} \times 100$, where WAP is working-age population (16+ and not institutionalized). The employment-population ratio is $\frac{E}{WAP} \times 100$. Unemployment varies by demographic group, region, and industry. The three types of unemployment are: frictional (short-term, search-related), structural (mismatch of skills or location), and cyclical (due to business cycle). Full employment occurs when cyclical unemployment is zero—only frictional and structural unemployment remain. The natural rate of unemployment is the sum of frictional and structural unemployment, typically estimated between 4% and 5% in the U.S. Actual unemployment fluctuates around the natural rate.
key_concept.context: Systematic measurement of unemployment began during the Great Depression, when the need for labor market data became urgent. The Current Population Survey started in 1940 and has been conducted monthly ever since. The definition of unemployment—actively seeking work—has been debated. Critics argue it understates true joblessness by excluding discouraged workers and underemployed part-time workers. Alternative measures (U-1 through U-6) provide broader perspectives. The natural rate concept, developed by Milton Friedman and Edmund Phelps in the 1960s, transformed how economists think about unemployment. It suggests that monetary policy cannot permanently reduce unemployment below the natural rate without causing accelerating inflation. This insight led to the Non-Accelerating Inflation Rate of Unemployment (NAIRU) concept. In AP Macroeconomics, understanding unemployment is essential for analyzing business cycles, evaluating policy, and understanding the tradeoff between inflation and unemployment (the Phillips Curve).

classifications.value: Short-term unemployment from normal labor market turnover
classifications.behavior: Frictional unemployment exists because it takes time to match workers with jobs. Workers may quit to find better opportunities; graduates enter the labor force; people relocate and search for new jobs. This unemployment is usually short-term (weeks to months) and actually reflects a dynamic, healthy economy where workers have choices. Some frictional unemployment is desirable—it allows better matches between workers and jobs, increasing productivity and satisfaction.

image.alt: Diagram showing worker moving from old job to new job with search period in between
image.caption: Figure 2.3.4: Frictional unemployment occurs during the search period between jobs. It's usually short-term.

examples.explanation: A worker quits a job to look for a better opportunity. While searching, they're frictionally unemployed. This is voluntary and usually brief.
College graduates entering the labor force for the first time. They may take weeks or months to find their first job, contributing to frictional unemployment.
Someone who took time off to raise children or travel now re-enters the labor force and searches for work. They're frictionally unemployed during the search.
A worker relocates to a new city and searches for a job there. The search period counts as frictional unemployment.

classifications.note: Frictional unemployment is not a problem to be solved—it's a sign of a dynamic economy. Policies that improve information (job boards, recruiting services) can reduce its duration.

classifications.value: Long-term unemployment from mismatch between skills and jobs
classifications.behavior: Structural unemployment arises when the skills workers have don't match the skills employers need, or when jobs are in different locations than workers. This can result from technological change (automation eliminates某些 jobs), international competition (jobs move overseas), or long-term shifts in the economy. Structural unemployment tends to last longer than frictional unemployment and often requires retraining, relocation, or other adjustments. It's more serious and costly than frictional unemployment.

image.alt: Diagram showing mismatch between workers' skills and available jobs, with retraining needed
image.caption: Figure 2.3.5: Structural unemployment occurs when workers' skills don't match available jobs. Retraining may be needed.

examples.explanation: Automation eliminates assembly line jobs. Former factory workers lack skills for new tech jobs. They're structurally unemployed until they retrain.
Textile production moves overseas. Domestic textile workers lose jobs but may not have skills for growing industries like healthcare or technology.
Coal mining declines as energy sources shift. Miners in rural areas can't easily find new jobs locally and may be unwilling or unable to relocate.
Jobs are abundant in cities, but workers are in rural areas with declining industries. Moving is costly, so structural unemployment persists.

classifications.note: Structural unemployment is more serious than frictional. It often requires policy responses: education and training programs, relocation assistance, or economic development in affected areas.

classifications.behavior: Cyclical unemployment results from insufficient aggregate demand. During recessions, firms produce less and lay off workers. These workers are unemployed not because of personal choices or skill mismatches, but because the economy isn't generating enough jobs. Cyclical unemployment rises during recessions and falls during expansions. It's the focus of stabilization policy—fiscal and monetary policy aim to reduce cyclical unemployment by stimulating demand.

image.alt: Graph showing unemployment rising during recessions and falling during expansions
image.caption: Figure 2.3.6: Cyclical unemployment rises during recessions and falls during expansions, following the business cycle.

examples.explanation: The Great Recession caused cyclical unemployment to spike to 10% in 2009. As the economy recovered, cyclical unemployment gradually fell.
COVID-19 caused massive layoffs as businesses closed. Unemployment spiked to 14.8% in April 2020—almost entirely cyclical. As the economy reopened, it fell rapidly.
During a recession, car sales fall. Auto manufacturers lay off workers. These workers are cyclically unemployed—they'll be rehired when demand recovers.

classifications.note: Cyclical unemployment is the focus of macroeconomic stabilization policy. Stimulus spending, tax cuts, and lower interest rates aim to boost demand and reduce cyclical unemployment.

principles.principle: The Unemployment Rate Doesn't Tell the Whole Story
principles.statement: The official unemployment rate (U-3) counts only those actively looking for work. It excludes discouraged workers—people who have given up looking because they believe no jobs are available. It also counts part-time workers who want full-time work as employed. During recessions, the official rate understates labor market distress because discouraged workers drop out of the labor force and part-time workers increase. Alternative measures (U-4 through U-6) provide broader perspectives. U-4 adds discouraged workers; U-5 adds marginally attached workers; U-6 adds those working part-time for economic reasons. These broader measures typically show more distress, especially during recessions.
principles.application: When interpreting unemployment reports, look beyond the headline rate. Check labor force participation—if it's falling, the unemployment rate may be artificially low. Check U-6 for a fuller picture of underemployment. Compare across demographic groups—unemployment rates for teenagers, minorities, and less-educated workers are typically higher. A low unemployment rate with falling participation may signal hidden distress, not a strong labor market.
principles.example: In April 2020, the official unemployment rate peaked at 14.8%. But U-6, which includes discouraged workers and part-time for economic reasons, peaked at 22.8%. Millions more were underemployed or had given up looking. The official rate, while alarming, understated the true labor market distress. As the economy recovered, both rates fell, but the gap narrowed slowly.

image.alt: Graph comparing U-3 official unemployment rate with U-6 broader measure over time
image.caption: Figure 2.3.7: U-6 (including discouraged and part-time for economic reasons) is typically higher than the official U-3 rate, especially during recessions.

principles.principle: The Natural Rate of Unemployment is Not Zero
principles.statement: Even in a healthy, growing economy, some unemployment exists. Frictional unemployment is inevitable as workers move between jobs. Structural unemployment may persist due to ongoing economic changes. The natural rate of unemployment is the sum of frictional and structural unemployment—the rate that prevails when the economy is at full employment, with no cyclical unemployment. Estimates of the natural rate vary over time but are typically between 4% and 5% in the U.S. When actual unemployment is below the natural rate, the economy may be overheating, leading to accelerating inflation. When it's above, the economy has cyclical unemployment and may need stimulus.
principles.application: The natural rate is a benchmark for policy. If unemployment is above the natural rate, policymakers may stimulate the economy to reduce cyclical unemployment. If it's below, they may worry about inflation and tighten policy. But the natural rate is not directly observable—it must be estimated, and estimates are uncertain. This complicates policy decisions. The concept also implies that there's a tradeoff only between unemployment and inflation when unemployment deviates from the natural rate—not a permanent tradeoff.
principles.example: In the late 1990s, unemployment fell below 4%, below most estimates of the natural rate. Yet inflation remained low. This puzzled economists and led to revisions in natural rate estimates. The experience showed that the natural rate can change over time and that the relationship between unemployment and inflation is not stable.

image.alt: Graph showing actual unemployment fluctuating around the natural rate over time
image.caption: Figure 2.3.8: Actual unemployment fluctuates around the natural rate. When above, cyclical unemployment exists; when below, economy may be overheating.

principles.principle: Unemployment Has Significant Economic and Social Costs
principles.statement: Unemployment imposes costs beyond lost income. For individuals, unemployment leads to skill depreciation, psychological distress, health problems, and long-term earnings losses. For society, unemployment means lost output—goods and services that could have been produced but weren't. Okun's Law quantifies this relationship: each percentage point of unemployment above the natural rate is associated with about a 2% loss in GDP. High unemployment also increases government spending on unemployment benefits and reduces tax revenue, worsening budget deficits. Long-term unemployment is especially damaging, as skills atrophy and workers become detached from the labor force.
principles.application: When evaluating unemployment, consider both the level and the duration. Long-term unemployment is more damaging than short-term. Policies should address not just the number unemployed but also the composition. Training programs may help the long-term unemployed. Extended unemployment benefits provide income support but may also reduce job search intensity—a tradeoff. The costs of unemployment justify policy intervention to stabilize the economy and reduce cyclical fluctuations.
principles.example: During the Great Recession, long-term unemployment (27+ weeks) reached record highs. Nearly half the unemployed had been jobless for six months or more. These workers faced permanent earnings losses, increased health problems, and higher risk of dropping out of the labor force. The social costs far exceeded the measured loss of output, justifying aggressive policy responses.

image.alt: Diagram showing economic costs (lost output) and social costs (health, family, skills) of unemployment
image.caption: Figure 2.3.9: Unemployment imposes economic costs (lost GDP) and social costs (health, skills, family stress).

principles.principle: Full Employment Means No Cyclical Unemployment
principles.statement: Full employment does not mean zero unemployment. It means the economy is operating at the natural rate—only frictional and structural unemployment exist. At full employment, everyone who wants a job at prevailing wages can find one, though search takes time. The economy is producing at its potential output. Full employment is sometimes called the Non-Accelerating Inflation Rate of Unemployment (NAIRU) because unemployment below this level tends to cause inflation to accelerate. Policymakers aim to keep the economy at full employment—not too high (wasted resources) and not too low (inflationary pressure).
principles.application: When analyzing the economy, compare actual unemployment to estimates of the natural rate/NAIRU. If actual is above, there's a output gap—the economy is producing below potential. Policy should stimulate demand. If actual is below, the economy may be overheating, and policy should cool demand. But estimates are uncertain, so policymakers must balance risks. The concept of full employment guides both fiscal and monetary policy.
principles.example: In 2019, U.S. unemployment fell to 3.5%, a 50-year low. Most estimates of the natural rate were around 4-4.5%. Yet inflation remained moderate. Was the economy above full employment? Possibly, but the relationship had changed. The Fed proceeded cautiously, raising rates slowly. The experience showed that full employment is a useful concept but not a precise target.

image.alt: Graph showing potential GDP and actual GDP with output gaps
image.caption: Figure 2.3.10: At full employment, the economy produces at potential GDP. Above potential, inflationary pressure; below potential, cyclical unemployment.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Unemployment and Labor Force Statistics

image.alt: Table of population data for unemployment calculation exercise
image.caption: Figure 2.3.11: Use this population data to calculate labor force statistics.

worked_examples.problem: A country has a working-age population of 200 million people. Of these, 120 million are employed, 15 million are unemployed and actively seeking work, 10 million are discouraged workers (have given up looking), 5 million are students not working, 20 million are retirees, and the rest are stay-at-home parents. a) Calculate the labor force. b) Calculate the official unemployment rate (U-3). c) Calculate the labor force participation rate. d) Calculate the U-4 unemployment rate (includes discouraged workers). e) Calculate the employment-population ratio.

step_by_step.explanation: Labor force = Employed + Unemployed (actively seeking). Employed = 120 million. Unemployed = 15 million. Labor force = 120 + 15 = 135 million.
Labor force participation rate = (Labor Force / Working-Age Population) × 100 = (135 / 200) × 100 = 67.5%.
U-4 adds discouraged workers to both unemployed and labor force. Unemployed + discouraged = 15 + 10 = 25 million. Labor force + discouraged = 135 + 10 = 145 million. U-4 = (25 / 145) × 100 = 17.2%.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Labor force = 135 million. b) U-3 = 11.1%. c) Labor force participation = 67.5%. d) U-4 = 17.2%. e) Employment-population ratio = 60%.
worked_examples.concept_applied: The official unemployment rate excludes discouraged workers. Broader measures show more labor market distress.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Types of Unemployment

image.alt: Scenarios describing different workers' situations for classification exercise
image.caption: Figure 2.3.12: Classify each worker as frictionally, structurally, or cyclically unemployed.

worked_examples.problem: Classify each of the following as frictional, structural, or cyclical unemployment. Explain your reasoning. a) Maria quit her job as a teacher to relocate to another state and is looking for a teaching job there. b) John was laid off from an auto plant during a recession when car sales plummeted. c) Chen's skills as a factory worker are no longer needed because the factory automated and his skills don't match available jobs. d) Sarah just graduated from college and is interviewing for jobs. e) A construction worker was laid off because the housing bubble burst and new home construction stopped. f) A textile worker lost her job when the factory moved to Vietnam and she lacks skills for other local jobs.

step_by_step.explanation: Maria quit voluntarily to relocate and is searching for a teaching job. This is normal labor market turnover—she's between jobs. Classification: Frictional unemployment.
John was laid off because of a recession—weak aggregate demand reduced car sales. When the economy recovers, he'll likely be rehired. Classification: Cyclical unemployment.
Chen's skills are obsolete due to automation. The jobs that exist require different skills. This is a mismatch, not a temporary demand problem. Classification: Structural unemployment.
Sarah is a new graduate entering the labor force. She's searching for her first job. This is normal labor market entry. Classification: Frictional unemployment.
Laid off because the housing bubble burst—a cyclical downturn in construction. When the housing market recovers, he'll likely be rehired. Classification: Cyclical unemployment.
Lost job due to globalization—the factory moved overseas. Local jobs don't match her skills. This is structural, not cyclical. Classification: Structural unemployment.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Frictional—voluntary job change. b) Cyclical—due to recession. c) Structural—skills obsolete. d) Frictional—new entrant. e) Cyclical—housing bust. f) Structural—globalization.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Frictional = temporary/search; Structural = mismatch; Cyclical = due to business cycle.

worked_examples.title: Okun's Law and the Costs of Unemployment

image.alt: Graph showing relationship between unemployment gap and GDP gap
image.caption: Figure 2.3.13: Okun's Law shows the relationship between unemployment and output gaps.

worked_examples.problem: An economy has a natural rate of unemployment of 5%. Actual unemployment is currently 8%. Potential GDP is $20$ trillion. Okun's Law states that each percentage point of unemployment above the natural rate is associated with a 2% loss of GDP relative to potential. a) What is the unemployment gap? b) What is the GDP gap (percentage)? c) What is the actual GDP? d) If unemployment falls to 6% next year, what will actual GDP be? e) What does this illustrate about the costs of cyclical unemployment?

step_by_step.explanation: Unemployment gap = Actual unemployment - Natural rate = 8% - 5% = 3 percentage points above natural rate.
Okun's Law: each 1% unemployment gap → 2% GDP gap. So GDP gap = 3 × 2% = 6%. This means actual GDP is 6% below potential.
Actual GDP = Potential GDP × (1 - GDP gap) = $20$ trillion × (1 - 0.06) = $20$ trillion × 0.94 = $18.8$ trillion. The economy is producing $\$1.2$ trillion less than it could.
If unemployment falls to 6%, new unemployment gap = 6% - 5% = 1%. New GDP gap = 1 × 2% = 2%. Actual GDP = $20$ trillion × 0.98 = $19.6$ trillion. Output increases by $\$0.8$ trillion.

Cyclical unemployment imposes huge costs. A 3% unemployment gap costs $\$1.2$ trillion in lost output—about $\$3,600$ per person. This doesn't include social costs like health problems, family stress, and skill loss. Reducing cyclical unemployment has enormous benefits.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Unemployment gap = 3%. b) GDP gap = 6%. c) Actual GDP = $18.8 trillion. d) With 6% unemployment, GDP = $19.6 trillion. e) Cyclical unemployment causes massive output losses.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Okun's Law quantifies the output cost of cyclical unemployment. Reducing unemployment has large economic benefits.

process_flow.description: Each month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics surveys about 60,000 households, asking about work activities during the reference week (the week containing the 12th of the month).
process_flow.mechanism: Trained interviewers contact households by phone or in person. Questions determine employment status, hours worked, job search activities, and reasons for not working.
process_flow.result: Raw data on employment status for a representative sample of the population.

image.alt: Diagram showing BLS interviewers surveying households
image.caption: Figure 2.3.14: Step 1 - BLS surveys 60,000 households monthly about work activities.

process_flow.description: Based on survey responses, each individual 16+ and not institutionalized is classified as employed, unemployed, or not in labor force.
process_flow.mechanism: Employed: worked for pay at least 1 hour, or had a job but temporarily absent. Unemployed: no work, available, and actively looked in past 4 weeks. Not in labor force: all others.
process_flow.result: Counts of employed (E), unemployed (U), and not in labor force (NLF).

image.alt: Flowchart showing decision tree for classifying individuals
image.caption: Figure 2.3.15: Step 2 - Classify each person as employed, unemployed, or not in labor force based on responses.

process_flow.description: Using the classified counts, calculate the unemployment rate, labor force participation rate, and employment-population ratio.
process_flow.mechanism: Labor Force = E + U. Unemployment Rate = U / LF × 100. Labor Force Participation Rate = LF / Working-Age Population × 100. Employment-Population Ratio = E / Working-Age Population × 100.
process_flow.result: Headline unemployment rate and other key statistics.

image.alt: Formulas for unemployment rate, labor force participation rate, employment-population ratio
image.caption: Figure 2.3.16: Step 3 - Calculate unemployment rate, labor force participation rate, and employment-population ratio.

process_flow.description: Raw data are adjusted for regular seasonal patterns (holiday hiring, summer jobs, school schedules) to reveal underlying trends.
process_flow.mechanism: Seasonal adjustment uses statistical models to estimate and remove regular within-year patterns. The seasonally adjusted data show changes that aren't due to predictable seasonal factors.
process_flow.result: Seasonally adjusted unemployment rate, the number reported in the news.

image.alt: Graph showing raw data with seasonal pattern and seasonally adjusted smooth line
image.caption: Figure 2.3.17: Step 4 - Seasonal adjustment removes regular patterns to reveal underlying trends.

process_flow.description: The BLS releases the Employment Situation report on the first Friday of each month, providing detailed labor market data.
process_flow.mechanism: Data are published with extensive tables by demographic group, industry, and duration of unemployment. Economists and policymakers analyze the data to assess labor market conditions.
process_flow.result: Monthly jobs report, influencing policy and financial markets.

image.alt: Example of monthly jobs report headline numbers
image.caption: Figure 2.3.18: Step 5 - BLS releases monthly jobs report with unemployment rate, payroll employment, and other data.

summary: Unemployment is a key indicator of labor market health and overall economic performance. The unemployment rate is the percentage of the labor force that is unemployed and actively seeking work. The labor force includes employed and unemployed individuals; those not working and not seeking work (students, retirees, discouraged workers) are not in the labor force. The labor force participation rate and employment-population ratio provide additional perspectives on labor market conditions. Unemployment is not a uniform phenomenon—economists distinguish three main types. Frictional unemployment is short-term unemployment from normal labor market turnover: workers moving between jobs, new entrants, and re-entrants. It's usually brief and even beneficial, allowing better job matches. Structural unemployment results from mismatches between workers' skills and job requirements, often due to technological change, globalization, or geographic immobility. It tends to be longer-term and more serious. Cyclical unemployment is caused by economic downturns and insufficient aggregate demand. It rises during recessions and falls during expansions. The natural rate of unemployment is the sum of frictional and structural unemployment—the rate that exists when the economy is at full employment with no cyclical unemployment. Estimates of the natural rate vary but are typically between 4% and 5% in the U.S. Actual unemployment fluctuates around the natural rate over the business cycle. Full employment does not mean zero unemployment—it means the economy is operating at the natural rate, producing at potential output. Unemployment imposes significant costs: lost output (quantified by Okun's Law, which finds each percentage point of unemployment above the natural rate reduces GDP by about 2%), lost income for workers, skill depreciation, psychological distress, and social problems. Long-term unemployment is especially damaging. The official unemployment rate (U-3) has limitations—it excludes discouraged workers and counts part-time workers as employed. Broader measures (U-4 through U-6) provide a fuller picture of labor market distress. Understanding unemployment is essential for analyzing business cycles, evaluating economic policy, and assessing the health of the economy.
